citation.article-title: Desulfovibrio aespoeensis sp. nov., a mesophilic sulfate-reducing bacterium from deep groundwater at Äspö hard rock laboratory, Sweden.

p.s: Description of Desulfovibrio aespoeensis sp. nov.
Desulfovibrio aespoeensis (ae.spe.en'sis. M. L. adj. aespoeensis pertaining to Äspö, south-eastern Sweden)
Vibrioid-shaped cells are 0.5 μm in diameter and 1-7-2.5 μm long and occur singly.
Cells are motile and contain desulfoviridin.
In the presence of sulfate, lactate is utilized as the sole electron donor and carbon source.
Lactate is incompletely oxidized to acetate.
It grows lithoheterotrophically on H2 and acetate (as the carbon source).
Pyruvate is fermented in the absence of sulfate.

The following substrates are not used in the presence or absence of sulfate: formate, succinate, methanol, fumarate, malate, 2-propanol, isobutanol, alanine, butyrate, phenol, benzoate, palmitate, ethanol and acetate.
Electron acceptors include sulfate, thiosulfate and sulfur.
Nitrate and iron(III) hydroxide are not used as electron acceptors.

Addition of NaCl is not required, but up to 30 g NaCl l-1 is tolerated, and optimum growth occurs in the presence of 7 g NaCl l-1 The temperature range for growth is 4-35°C, the optimum being 25-30°C.
The optimum pH for growth is 7.5.
The G + C content of DNA is 61 ± 0.5 mol% (as determined by thermal melting point profile).
The EMBL accession number for the 16s rRNA sequence of strain Aspo-2 is X95230. D. aespoeensis was isolated from deep subterranean granitic groundwater (600 m) of south-eastern Sweden.
The type strain is Aspo-2 (= DSM 10631).
